name: Moderate acute malnutrition death under 5 years
definition: Death in child under 5 years with moderate acute malnutrition (MAM)
definitionExtended: The ICD 10 code is E44 and E46. The criteria for MAM is:

name: Moderate acute malnutrition in child under 5 years new
definition: Child under 5 years with weight-for-length/height between -2 and -3 Z-score (all U5 children) or with MUAC from 11.5cm to 12.4 cm (among 6-59mo) and no oedema
definitionExtended: A child under 5 years with a weight-for-height between -2 and -3 Z-score and/or child (6-59 months) has a mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) from 11.5 to 12.4 cm and no oedema. Only record children presenting for the first time with moderate acute malnutrition (MAM) during this episode (i.e. new cases), not those coming for follow-up. A child previously identified with MAM that was cured (completed nutritional rehabilitation successfully), but who later develops MAM again should be counted again as a new case. Count the child regardless of the cause of MAM
useAndContext: Monitors prevention and diagnosis of moderate acute malnutrition in children under 5 years
inclusions: INCLUDE referrals from a private general practitioner
exclusions: EXCLUDE referrals from other state health facilities since these facilities would have already reported a new case of MAM under -5 years new
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register; OPD Register

name: Moderate acute malnutrition inpatient separation under 5 years
definition: An inpatient under 5 years with moderate acute malnutrition (MAM). This data item is only counted at separation. Count separation of a child under 5 years who was assessed as having MAM on admission
definitionExtended: The ICD 10 code is E44 and E46. The criteria for MAM is:

name: No acute malnutrition inpatient separation  under 5 years
definition: An inpatient under 5 years with no acute malnutrition (NAM)

name: Pneumonia death under 5 years
definition: A child under 5 years who died in a health facility where pneumonia was documented as the main cause of death
definitionExtended: Pneumonia is defined as cough and fast breathing. The definition of fast breathing depends on the age of the child:

name: Pneumonia new in child under 5 years
definition: Child under 5 years classified as pneumonia according to the IMCI definition
definitionExtended: Pneumonia is defined as cough or chest in drawing or stridor in calm child or difficult and fast breathing. The definition of fast breathing depends on the age of the child:

name: Pneumonia separation under 5 years
definition: Child under 5 years with pneumonia as main final diagnosis at separation
definitionExtended: The ICD 10 codes are J12-J22, B59, B25.0.

name: Severe acute malnutrition death under 5 years
definition: Death in child under 5 years with severe acute malnutrition (SAM)
definitionExtended: The ICD 10 codes are E40, E41, E42 and E43. A child under 5 years is classified to be severely malnourished if the child has a weight for height/length (WHL) below -3 Standard Deviation scores (<-3SD) and/or presence of bilateral pitting oedema and/or child (6-59 months) has a mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) of less than 115mm. The weight-for-age chart in the Road-to-Health Booklet shows body-weight relative to age in comparison to the median (0-line). All children under 5 years who were assessed as having SAM on admission must be reported here, irrespective of the main final diagnosis or cause of death (it does not imply that the child died from SAM). For example, a child who is assessed as having SAM dies from pneumonia, the child should be counted under Pneumonia death under 5 years AND under Death in child under 5 years with severe acute malnutrition (SAM)
useAndContext: Monitors the severity and management of SAM in children under 5 years of age
inclusions: INCLUDE all deaths in children under five years assessed as having SAM,INPATIENTS ONLY.
exclusions: EXCLUDE children with non-nutritional oedema.

name: Severe acute malnutrition death under 5 years
definition: Death in child under 5 years with severe acute malnutrition (SAM)
definitionExtended: The ICD 10 codes are E40, E41, E42 and E43. A child under 5 years is classified to be severely malnourished if the child has a weight for height/length (WHL) below -3 Standard Deviation scores (<-3SD) and/or presence of bilateral pitting oedema and/or child (6-59 months) has a mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) of less than 115mm. The weight-for-age chart in the Road-to-Health Booklet shows body-weight relative to age in comparison to the median (0-line). All children under 5 years who were assessed as having SAM on admission must be reported here, irrespective of the main final diagnosis or cause of death (it does not imply that the child died from SAM). For example, a child who is assessed as having SAM dies from pneumonia, the child should be counted under Pneumonia death under 5 years AND under Death in child under 5 years with severe acute malnutrition (SAM)
useAndContext: Monitors the severity and management of SAM in children under 5 years of age
inclusions: INCLUDE all deaths in children under five years assessed as having SAM

name: Severe acute malnutrition in child under 5 years new
definition: Child under 5 years with weight-for-length/height below -3 Z-score (all U5 children) or with MUAC <11.5 cm (among 6-59mo) or nutritional oedema of both feet (all U5 children)
definitionExtended: Only record children presenting for the first time with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) during this episode (i.e. new cases), not those coming for follow-up. A child previously identified with SAM that was cured (completed nutritional rehabilitation successfully), but who develops SAM again should be counted again as a new case . Count the child regardless of the cause of the severe malnutrition.
useAndContext: Monitors prevention and diagnosis of severe acute malnutrition in children under 5 years.
inclusions: INCLUDE referrals from a private general practitioner
exclusions: EXCLUDE referrals from other state health facilities, since these facilities would have already reported a case of severe malnutrition under 5 years new
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register; OPD Register

name: Severe acute malnutrition in child under 5 years new
definition: Child under 5 years with weight-for-length/height below -3 Z-score (all U5 children) or with MUAC <11.5 cm (among 6-59mo) or nutritional oedema of both feet (all U5 children)
definitionExtended: Only record children presenting for the first time with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) during this episode (i.e. new cases), not those coming for follow-up. A child previously identified with SAM that was cured (completed nutritional rehabilitation successfully), but who develops SAM again should be counted again as a new case . Count the child regardless of the cause of the severe malnutrition
useAndContext: Monitors prevention and diagnosis of severe acute malnutrition in children under 5 years.
inclusions: INCLUDE referrals from a private general practitioner
exclusions: EXCLUDE referrals from other state health facilities, since these facilities would have already reported a case of severe malnutrition under 5 years new
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register; OPD Register

name: Severe acute malnutrition inpatient separation  under 5 years
definition: An inpatient under 5 years with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). This data item is only counted at separation. Count separation of child under 5 years who was assessed as having SAM on admission
definitionExtended: The ICD 10 codes are E40, E41, E42, E43. A child under 5 years is classified to be severely malnourished if the child has a weight for height/length (WHL) below -3 Standard Deviation scores (<-3SD) and/or presence of bilateral pitting (nutritional) oedema and/or child (6-59 months) has a mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) of less than 115mm. The nutritional status of all U5 children must be assessed on admission and recorded as: SAM, MAM or no acute malnutrition (NAM). Although the assessment should be done on admission and recorded in case sheet, the data item is only reported at separation. Even though the child was admitted with diarrhoeal disease or pneumonia, the child must also be counted as having SAM
useAndContext: Monitors the severity and management of SAM in children under 5 years of age
inclusions: INCLUDE all children under five years assessed as having SAM
exclusions: EXCLUDE children with non-nutritional oedema;

name: Severe acute malnutrition inpatient separation  under 5 years
definition: An inpatient under 5 years with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). This data item is only counted at separation. Count separation of child under 5 years who was assessed as having SAM on admission
definitionExtended: The ICD 10 codes are E40, E41, E42, E43. A child under 5 years is classified to be severely malnourished if the child has a weight for height/length (WHL) below -3 Standard Deviation scores (<-3SD) and/or presence of bilateral pitting (nutritional) oedema and/or child (6-59 months) has a mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) of less than 115mm. The nutritional status of all U5 children must be assessed on admission and recorded as: SAM, MAM or no acute malnutrition (NAM). Although the assessment should be done on admission and recorded in case sheet, the data item is only reported at separation. Even though the child was admitted with diarrhoeal disease or pneumonia, the child must also be counted as having SAM.
useAndContext: Monitors the severity and management of SAM in children under 5 years of age
inclusions: INCLUDE all children under five years assessed as having SAM
exclusions: EXCLUDE children with non-nutritional oedema

name: Vitamin A dose 12-59 months
definition: Vitamin A dose given to a child, preferably every six months from 12 to 59 months
definitionExtended: Deworming medication must be given together with the Vitamin A. Consisting of a single dose of 200,000 IU. Routine Vitamin A supplementation strengthens the immune system of children. Routine Vitamin A supplementation consisting of a single dose every 6 months until 59 months (4 year 11 months). Children receiving routine multivitamin syrup can still receive routine Vitamin A supplementation. If a child is scheduled to receive a routine prophylactic dose of Vitamin A and has received a treatment dose within the past month, the routine dose should be postponed for one month. Record only the doses given as part of the Vitamin A immunisation schedule. The dose given should also be recorded on the Road to Health booklet. Vit A doses given by WBPHCOTs in households and by school health nurses at schools should be counted
useAndContext: Monitors the implementation of the Vit A policy for children under 5 years of age
inclusions: INCLUDE Vitamin A dose given by CHWs as part of community service

name: Vitamin A dose 12-59 months
definition: Vitamin A dose given to a child, preferably every six months from 12 to 59 months
definitionExtended: Deworming medication must be given together with the Vitamin A. Consisting of a single dose of 200,000 IU. Routine Vitamin A supplementation strengthens the immune system of children. Routine Vitamin A supplementation consisting of a single dose every 6 months until 59 months (4 year 11 months). Children receiving routine multivitamin syrup can still receive routine Vitamin A supplementation. If a child is scheduled to receive a routine prophylactic dose of Vitamin A and has received a treatment dose within the past month, the routine dose should be postponed for one month. Record only the doses given as part of the Vitamin A immunisation schedule. The dose given should also be recorded on the Road to Health booklet. VitA doses given by WBPHCOTs in households and by school health nurses at schools should be counted.
useAndContext: Monitors the implementation of the Vit A policy for children under 5 years of age
inclusions: INCLUDE Vitamin A dose given by CHWs as part of community service; INCLUDE Vitamin A given at schools/crèches as part of school health service; INCLUDE local mop-up activities
exclusions: EXCLUDE Vitamin A supplement given as part of a mass national campaigns;

name: Bilharzia new case reported
definition: Total bilharzia new cases  reported
definitionExtended: Count all cases of bilharzia new cases reported
useAndContext: Monitor new cases of reported bilharzia
inclusions: INCLUDE all the bilharzia new cases reported , whether clinically or laboratory confirmed (Schistosomiasis Mansoni, Schistosomiasis Japonicum, Schistosomiasis Haematobium)

name: Malaria death reported
definition: Malaria death reported as a result or confirmed from primary malaria diagnosis(rapid diagnostic and microscopy tests ) at the time of death
useAndContext: Monitors the progress of South Africa towards elimination of malaria cases.

name: Malaria new case reported
definition: Parasitological-confirmed malaria cases reported in South Africa (includes both local transmission and imported cases)
definitionExtended: All cumulative malaria cases from the beginning of financial year
useAndContext: Monitors the progress of South Africa towards elimination of malaria cases.
inclusions: INCLUDE all parasitological confirmed malaria cases tested by both rapid diagnostic tests and microscopy tests conducted in health facilities or laboratories
tools: Notification Forms, Malaria Surveillance, Laboratory Databases

name: TB Rifampicin Resistant /MDR confirmed client
definition: TB clients confirmed with Rifampicin resistant  (RR) and or  Multidrug - Resistant (MDR)  TB
definitionExtended: These are patients diagnosed with Rifampicin resistant/MDR regardless of diagnostic method
useAndContext: Monitors disease burden and effectiveness of case finding strategy.
inclusions: INCLUDE clients diagnosed using TB NAAT, Culture and DST tests
exclusions: EXCLUDE clients started on treatment based on clinical suspicion and resistance pattern of index case, exclude pre-XDR

name: TB Rifampicin Resistant /MDR confirmed client start on treatment
definition: TB Rifampicin resistant (RR) and or Multidrug - Resistant (MDR) TB  clients  started on treatment
definitionExtended: These are clients diagnosed with Rifampicin Resistant TB, with or without isoniazid resistance.
useAndContext: Measure of linkage to treatment and addresses the second 90 of the 90-90-90 strategy

name: TB Rifampicin Resistant/ MDR death
definition: TB Rifampicin resistant (RR) and Multidrug - Resistant (MDR) TB clients who died during treatment
definitionExtended: Clients who die from any cause during the course of treatment. The cause of death may not necessarily be due to TB .

name: TB Rifampicin Resistant/ MDR lost to follow-up
definition: TB Rifampicin resistant (RR) and  Multiple drug resistant (MDR) TB clients who are lost to follow-up during the treatment
definitionExtended: A client whose treatment was interrupted for 2 consecutive months or more
useAndContext: Monitors retention in care
inclusions: INCLUDE clients started on treatment based on clinical suspicion and resistance pattern of index case
exclusions: EXCLUDE Pre-XDR and XDR clients

name: EMS P1 rural response
definition: Total P1 responses in the rural area
definitionExtended: P1 (Priority 1) refer to emergency calls where the patient has life-threatening injuries or illnesses and urgently need medical management at an appropriate medical facility, These calls require urgent response by an ambulance in a rural area.
useAndContext: Response time is the time it takes an ambulance to reach the patient; calculated from the time the call is received by the control room up to the time of arrival of the first emergency unit on scene
collectedBy: EMS personnel, Data capturers/Admin Assistants for EMS
tools: EMS Province specific data collections tools

name: EMS P1 rural response under 60 minutes
definition: P1 responses in a rural area where the response time was under 60 minutes
definitionExtended: P1 (Priority 1) refer to emergency calls where the patient has life-threatening injuries or illnesses and urgently need medical management at an appropriate medical facility, These calls require urgent response by an ambulance in a rural area within 60 minutes of the call being received.
useAndContext: Response time is the time it takes an ambulance to reach the patient; calculated from the time the call is received by the control room up to the time of arrival of the first emergency unit on scene
collectedBy: EMS personnel, Data capturers/Admin Assistants for EMS
tools: EMS Province specific data collections tools

name: EMS P1 urban response
definition: Total P1 responses in an urban area
definitionExtended: P1 (Priority 1) refer to emergency calls where the patient has life-threatening injuries or illnesses and urgently need medical management at an appropriate medical facility, These calls require urgent response by an ambulance in an urban area
useAndContext: Response time is the time it takes an ambulance to reach the patient; calculated from the time the first call is received by the control room up to the time of arrival of the first emergency unit on scene
collectedBy: EMS personnel, Data capturers/Admin Assistants for EMS
tools: EMS Province specific data collections tools

name: EMS P1 urban response under 30 minutes
definition: P1 responses in an urban area where the response time was under 30 minutes
definitionExtended: P1 (Priority 1) refer to emergency calls where the patient has life-threatening injuries or illnesses and urgently need medical management at an appropriate medical facility, These calls require urgent response by an ambulance in an urban area within 30 minutes of the call being received
useAndContext: Response time is the time it takes an ambulance to reach the patient; calculated from the time the first call is received by the control room up to the time of arrival of the first emergency unit on scene
collectedBy: EMS personnel, Data capturers/Admin Assistants for EMS
tools: EMS Province specific data collections tools

name: BCG dose
definition: BCG (tuberculosis) vaccine given to a child under one year of age at birth. The cut-off age is under 12 months
definitionExtended: All babies or infants receiving BCG should be counted, including babies coming to clinics after home deliveries and babies or infants who received their BCG later than usual due to e.g. temporary shortages of vaccine. BCG should still be given to HIV exposed children. Tuberculosis (TB) is a mycobacterial disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and is a major cause of disability and death in many parts of the world. Do not give BCG vaccine to children who are sick with AIDS and other immunosuppressive conditions. Do not give BCG to a new-born if the mother is on anti-TB drugs. Do not give BCG to a child who is older than 12 months.

name: DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV (Hexavalent) 1st dose
definition: DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV (also known as Hexavalent) 1st dose vaccination given to a child under one year at 6 weeks after birth. The cut-off age is under 12 months.
definitionExtended: This includes children under one year receiving their 1st dose of Hexavalent. DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV 1st dose is given together with OPV, PCV and RV. DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV is given to children at 6, 10 and 14 weeks and at 18 months
useAndContext: Monitors the Expanded Programme on Immunisation policy
exclusions: EXCLUDE vaccines given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

name: DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV (Hexavalent) 2nd dose
definition: DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV (also known as Hexavalent) 2nd dose vaccination given to a child under one year at 10 weeks after birth. The cut-off age is under 12 months.
definitionExtended: This includes children under one year receiving their 2nd dose of Hexavalent. DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV 2nd dose is given at 10 weeks
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against diphtheria, tetanus, a-cellular pertussis, polio, Haemophilus influenza and Hepatitis B
exclusions: EXCLUDE vaccines given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

name: DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV (Hexavalent) 3rd dose
definition: DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV (also known as Hexavalent) 3rd dose vaccination given to a child under one year at 14 weeks after birth. The cut-off age is under 12 months. Refer to the Standard Treatment Guidelines for Immunisation.
definitionExtended: This includes children under one year receiving their 3rd dose of Hexavalent. DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV 3rd dose is given together with PCV2 and RV2. DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV is given to children at 6, 10 and 14 weeks and at 18 months
useAndContext: Monitors the Expanded Programme on Immunisation policy
exclusions: EXCLUDE vaccines given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

name: DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV (Hexavalent) 4th dose
definition: DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV (also known as Hexavalent) 4th dose vaccination given to a child at 18 months after birth. The cut-off age is under 24 months
definitionExtended: The numerator  includes children up to 2 years of age receiving their 4th dose of Hexavalent. DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV is given to children at 6, 10 and 14 weeks and at 18 months
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against diphtheria, tetanus, a-cellular pertussis, polio, Haemophilus influenza and Hepatitis B. DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV (known as Hexavalent) was implemented in 2015 to replace DTaP-IPV/Hib (Pentaxim) and HepB
exclusions: EXCLUDE vaccines given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

name: Immunised fully under 1 year new
definition: A child who have completed his or her primary course of immunisation before the age of one year.
definitionExtended: The child must have received all primary doses before 12 months of age (BCG; OPV 0 &1; DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV 1, 2 and 3; RV 1 and 2; PCV 1, 2 and 3 & MR 1).  Only doses received before 12 months of age should be counted as fully immunised AND there is documentary proof of all administered primary doses
useAndContext: The child should only be counted ONCE as fully immunised when receiving the last vaccine in the course (usually PCV3 vaccine) AND if there is documented proof of all required vaccines (BCG, OPV1, DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV 1, 2, 3, PCV 1,2,3, RV 1,2 and MR 1) on the Road to Health Card or Booklet AND the child is under 1 year old
inclusions: INCLUDE catch-up doses given to children before 1 year of age
exclusions: EXCLUDE catch-up doses given after 1 year of age

name: MR 1st dose
definition: Measles or Measles Rubella (MR) vaccine 1st dose given to a child under one year of age at 6 months after birth. The cut-off age is under 12 months
definitionExtended: Children under 1 year who received Measles or MR 1st dose, as a proportion of population under 1 year. Both Measles and MR doses will form part of the numerator to ensure accurate coverage of historical data. All children older than 12 months who have missed the 1st dose of MR vaccine at 6 months, should receive this dose immediately and receive the second dose with a 4 week interval. Record dose given on the Road to Health Booklet and Patient Register
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against Measles and Rubella viruses
inclusions: INCLUDE all catch-up doses given to children under 12 months of age
exclusions: EXCLUDE catch-up doses given to children aged 12 months and above

name: MR 2nd dose
definition: Measles Rubella vaccine 2nd dose given to a child at 12 months after birth. The cut-off age is under 24 months
definitionExtended: Children 12 months old who received Measles or MR 2nd dose, as a proportion of the 1 year population. Both Measles and MR doses will form part of the numerator to ensure accurate coverage of historical data. All children aged 24 months and above who have missed the 1st Measles or MR dose at 6 months, should receive this dose immediately and receive the second dose within a 4 week interval. If any child older than 24 months who has not received 1st and 2nd dose of Measles or MR vaccine, the missed doses should be given with an interval of 4  weeks between 1st and 2nd dose and dose(s) should be recorded under the catch-up file and not under routine file of the DHIS. Record dose given on the Road to Health Booklet and Patient Register
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against Measles & MR viruses. Because the 1st Measles & Rubella dose is only around 85% effective the 2nd dose is important as a booster
inclusions: INCLUDE all catch-up doses given to children under 24 months of age
exclusions: EXCLUDE catch-up doses given to children aged 24 months and above

name: OPV 0 dose under 1 year
definition: Oral polio Vaccine  (OPV) 0 dose given to a child under 1 year at birth. The cut-off age is under 6 months.
definitionExtended: OPV is given together with BCG at birth
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against Polio. Vaccines given as part of mass vaccination campaigns should not be counted here
inclusions: INCLUDE BBAs if they are given BCG

name: OPV 1st dose under 1 year
definition: Oral polio Vaccine 1st dose given to a child under 1 year at 6 weeks. The cut-off age is under 12 months
definitionExtended: OPV 1st is given to children at 6 weeks. OPV 1st dose is given together with RV1, DTaP-IPV-Hib_HBV 1 and PCV1 at 6 weeks
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against Polio
exclusions: EXCLUDE vaccines given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

name: PCV 1st dose under 1 year
definition: Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine 1st dose given to a child under 1 year at 6 weeks. The cut-off age is under 12 months
definitionExtended: PCV is given to children at 6, 14 weeks and 9 months. PCV 1st dose is given together with OPV1, DTaP-IPV-Hib_HBV 1 and RV1 at 6 weeks
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against Streptococcus pneumonia.
exclusions: EXCLUDE vaccines given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

name: PCV 2nd dose under 1 year
definition: Pneumococcal (PCV) vaccine 2nd dose given to a child under one year, at 14 weeks. The cut-off age is under 12 months
definitionExtended: PCV is given to children at 6, 14 weeks and 9 months. PCV2 is given together with RV2 and DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV 3 at 14 weeks
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against Streptococcus pneumonia.
exclusions: EXCLUDE vaccines given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

name: PCV 3rd dose under 1 year
definition: Pneumococcal (PCV) vaccine 3rd dose given to a child under one year, at 9 months after birth. The cut-off age is under 12 months
definitionExtended: PCV is given to children at 6 and 14 weeks and at 9 months. PCV 3rd dose is usually the last vaccine to be given for a child to be fully immunised
useAndContext: Monitors the Expanded Programme on Immunisation policy
exclusions: EXCLUDE vaccines given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

name: RV 1st dose under 1 year
definition: Rotavirus (RV) vaccine 1st dose given to a child at 6 weeks after birth. The cut-off age is under 20 weeks.
definitionExtended: RV is given to children at 6 and 14 weeks. RV 1st dose is given together with OPV1, DTaP-IPV-Hib_HBV 1 and PCV1 at 6 weeks
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against Rotaviruses.
exclusions: EXCLUDE vaccines given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

name: RV 2nd dose under 1 year
definition: Rotavirus (RV) vaccine 2nd dose given to a child under one year, at 14 weeks after birth and NOT later than 24 weeks after birth.
definitionExtended: If the child missed the 1st dose of RV at 6 weeks of age and is younger than 20 week, give the 1st dose and the 2nd dose 4 weeks later. Keep a minimum interval of 4 weeks between the 2 doses of RV. RV 2nd dose is given together with DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV and PCV
useAndContext: Monitors the Expanded Programme on Immunisation policy
exclusions: EXCLUDE vaccines given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

name: Tdap dose at 12 years
definition: Tdap booster dose given to a child at 12 years of age. The cut-off age is 14 years
definitionExtended: Tdap is tetanus plus diluted diphtheria plus acellular pertussis. Do not administer Tdap for children who are younger than 12 years of age
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis including vaccinations done at schools.
inclusions: INCLUDE doses given during catch-up campaigns to children between 12 and 14 years old

name: Tdap dose at 6 years
definition: Tdap booster dose given to a child at 6 years of age. The cut-off age is 9 years
definitionExtended: Tdap is tetanus plus diluted diphtheria plus acellular pertussis. Tdap dose is given at 6 years as a proportion of average population 6-9 years. Do not administer Tdap for children who are younger than 6 years of age
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis including vaccinations done at schools
inclusions: INCLUDE doses given during catch-up campaigns to children between 6 and 9 years

name: MR  dose 12-59 months  (campaign)
definition: MR vaccine  dose to 12-59 months children (campaign) coverage. Since our target population estimates are for the total child population in the 12-59 months age group, it will be divided by number of campaign  days
definitionExtended: MR vaccine  dose to 12-59 months children (campaign) coverage. Since our target population estimates are for the total child population in the 12-59 months age group, it will be divided by number of campaign  days
useAndContext: Most EPI campaigns tend to run for a variable length of time in some areas, due to logistical problems or staff shortages. The daily campaign coverage figures should therefore be used with care..
collectionPoints: All health facilities (Clinics, CHCs, Mobiles, ECD Centre & hospitals

name: EH domestic water bacteriological sample collected
definition: Domestic water samples collected (12 samples /10 000 population, plus an additional 120 samples) from piped water supplies, non-piped water supplies, tanked water, vended water, bottled water at a point of use or sale, (Criteria is  microbiological quality, E coli/faecal coliforms)
useAndContext: Monitors domestic microbiological water safety. It is used to monitor the safety of water used in residential areas, hospitality industry, food production, water outlets, schools and health facilities amongst other settings. It is key in identifying poor water quality that may lead to occurrences of waterborne diseases. Safe water is a key determinant of health and contribute to the NDP goals of raising the life expectancy of South Africans to at least 70 years, reducing maternal, infant and child mortality

name: EH domestic water bacteriological sample compliant
definition: Domestic drinking water samples collected and analysed from a Water Services Authority and Non Water Services Authority (Vessels, Aircrafts, farms, Transnet, etc.) that complied to the standards set out in SANS 241
definitionExtended: This should exclude samples collected in outbreaks and for other specific purposes. Routine analysis (normal water sampling schedule and points). Refers to E-coli and Coliform organisms
useAndContext: Domestic water samples collected (12 samples /10 000 population, plus an additional 120 samples) from piped water supplies, non-piped water supplies, tanked water, vended water at a point of use or sale that complied with the standard of 0/100ml E coli/faecal coliforms

name: EH food handling premises compliant
definition: Food handling premises inspected and in possession of a health Certificate of Acceptability (CoA), i.e. that comply with the minimum health standards as stipulated under Regulations R638, promulgated under FCD Act 54 of 1972.
useAndContext: R638, promulgated under FCD Act 54 of 1972.

name: EH food handling premises inspected
definition: Food handling premises inspected and assessed in terms of compliance with the minimum health standards as stipulated under Regulations  R638, promulgated under FCD Act 54 of 1972.
useAndContext: R638, promulgated under FCD Act 54 of 1972.

name: EH food sample bacteriological analysis
definition: Food samples taken for bacteriological analysis according to regulations promulgated in terms of the Foodstuffs, Cosmetics and Disinfectants Act, Act 54 0f 1972
useAndContext: This includes milk samples taken for bacteriological analysis. Exclude samples for exportation certification purposes.

name: EH food sample bacteriologically compliant
definition: Food samples bacteriologically analysed that complied with the Foodstuffs, Cosmetics and Disinfectants Act, Act 54 0f 1972
useAndContext: This includes milk samples taken for bacteriological analysis. Exclude samples for exportation certification purposes

name: EH food sample chemical analysis
definition: Food samples taken for chemical analysis according to the regulations promulgated in terms of the Foodstuffs, Cosmetics and Disinfectants Act, Act 54 0f 1972
useAndContext: This includes imported food stuffs, salt samples, milk samples taken for chemical analysis, samples for labelling and fortified food samples (maize meal and bread flour)

name: EH food sample chemically compliant
definition: Food samples chemically tested that complied with the Foodstuffs, Cosmetics and Disinfectants Act, Act 54 0f 1972
useAndContext: This includes imported food stuffs, salt samples, milk samples taken for chemical analysis, samples for labelling and fortified food samples (maize meal and bread flour)

name: EH hazardous substance dealer compliant
definition: Hazardous Substances (Group 1 A and B) dealers inspected that comply with the regulations for hazardous substances in the Environmental Health Programme
definitionExtended: All hazardous substances dealers must be inspected and compliant with the Hazardous Substances Act (Act 15 of 1973) and Regulations
useAndContext: Monitors hazardous substance dealer compliance

name: EH hazardous substance dealer inspected
definition: Hazardous Substance (Group 1 A and B) dealers inspected in the Environmental Health Programme
definitionExtended: All hazardous substances dealers must be inspected and compliant with Hazardous Substances Act (Act 15 of 1973) and Regulations
useAndContext: Monitors hazardous substance dealer compliance

name: EH health care waste generator compliant
definition: Health care waste generators inspected that complied with minimum standards according to National Environmental Health Norms and Standards
definitionExtended: All waste generators should be inspected at least once a year. Inspection should be done according to National Environmental Health Norms and Standards OR other applicable legislation. Only count the first inspection during the financial year. Don't include follow-up inspections.
useAndContext: Monitors compliance of health care waste generators.
inclusions: INCLUDE Only count the first inspection during the financial year (government financial year- 1 Apr- 31 Mar)
exclusions: EXCLUDE Follow-up inspections.

name: EH health care waste generator inspected
definition: Health care waste generators inspected according to  National Environmental Health Norms and Standards
definitionExtended: All waste generators should be inspected at least once a year. Inspection should be done according to SANS 10248 and any other applicable legislation. Only count the first inspection that comply during the financial year. Don't include follow-up inspections.
useAndContext: Monitors health care waste generator compliance

name: EH international conveyance arrival at first point of entry
definition: International conveyances arrivals at each international point of entry
definitionExtended: Conveyance shall include any conveyance as defined in terms of IHR
useAndContext: Monitors international conveyance inspection rate
exclusions: EXCLUDE none-commercial conveyances

name: EH international conveyance compliant at first point of entry
definition: International conveyance at arrival inspected for compliance to health standards as a proportion of international conveyance inspected at first point of entry
definitionExtended: Conveyance shall include any conveyance as defined in terms of IHR
useAndContext: Monitors international conveyance compliance rate

name: EH international conveyance inspected at first point of entry
definition: International conveyances inspected at each international point of entry
definitionExtended: Conveyance shall include any conveyance as defined in terms of IHR
useAndContext: Monitors international conveyance inspection rate

name: EH international imported consignment arrival at first point of entry
definition: International imported detained consignments arrived at each international point of entry
definitionExtended: Only consignment detained for port health inspection
useAndContext: Monitors international imported consignment inspection rate
exclusions: EXCLUDE consignments not detained for port health inspection

name: EH international imported consignment compliant at first point of entry
definition: International imported detained consignments compliant at each international point of entry in terms of the National Port Health Standard Operating legislation
definitionExtended: Only consignment detained for port health inspection
useAndContext: Monitors international imported consignment inspection rate
exclusions: EXCLUDE consignments not detained for port health inspection

name: EH international imported consignment inspected at first point of entry
definition: International imported detained consignments inspected at each international point of entry
definitionExtended: Only consignment detained for port health inspection
useAndContext: Monitors international imported consignment compliance rate
exclusions: EXCLUDE consignments not detained for port health inspection

name: EH international traveller compliant with yellow fever vaccination requirement
shortname: EH inter trav yellow fev comp
definition: Travellers arriving in a Port of Entry from yellow fever endemic areas that complied to the Yellow Fever Policy. Compliant travellers includes travellers with medical waiver letter.
definitionExtended: Only travellers from yellow fever endemic areas
useAndContext: Monitors spread of yellow fever between SA and other countries
inclusions: INCLUDE travellers with medical waiver letter

name: EH international traveller from yellow fever endemic countries
shortname: EH inter trav from yellow fev area
definition: Travellers arriving in a Port of Entry from yellow fever endemic areas
definitionExtended: Monitors spread of yellow fever between SA and other countries

name: EH milling establishment compliant
definition: Maize meal/bread flour mill establishments that were inspected and found to comply with the fortification regulation
definitionExtended: Regulation promulgated in terms of the Foodstuffs, Cosmetics and Disinfectants Act (Act 54 of 1972) and regulations promulgated in terms of the Act
useAndContext: Monitors flour and maize milling establishment compliance

name: EH milling establishment inspected
definition: Maize meal / bread flour mill establishment that were inspected
definitionExtended: Inspected according to regulation promulgated in terms of the Foodstuffs, Cosmetics and Disinfectants Act (Act 54 of 1972) and regulations promulgated in terms of the Act
useAndContext: Monitors flour and maize milling establishment compliance

name: Cataract surgery - total
definition: Number of eyes on which cataract surgery was performed
definitionExtended: Count each eye as cataract surgery performed. Cataract is opacity of the normally transparent lens
useAndContext: Monitors access to cataract surgery
inclusions: INCLUDE surgery with and without intraocular lens implants performed on clients of all ages

name: Spectacles issued to an adult  - total
definition: Number of spectacles issued to clients aged 19 years and older
definitionExtended: This should include all new spectacles issued to adults including a new pair every 2 years. However, this should exclude spectacles re-issued due to the original pair not working for the patient. These data must be collected by a facility that orders spectacles for clients
useAndContext: Monitors access to eye care services
inclusions: INCLUDE all adults 19 years and older who receive spectacles (both ready made and custom made spectacles) at public health facilities
exclusions: EXCLUDE spectacles re ordered due to wrong script or not working as expected.

name: Spectacles issued to child- total
definition: Number of spectacles issued to clients aged 7-18 years of age
definitionExtended: This should include all new spectacles issued to children including a new pair every 2 years. However, this should exclude spectacles re-issued due to the original pair not working for the patient. These data must be collected by a facility that orders spectacles for clients
useAndContext: Monitors access to eye care services
inclusions: INCLUDE all children aged 7-18 years who receive spectacles (both ready made and custom made spectacles) at public health facilities
exclusions: EXCLUDE spectacles re ordered due to wrong script or not working as expected.

name: Spectacles required by an adult - total
definition: Spectacles (ordered) required for clients aged 19 years and above
definitionExtended: This should exclude re-orders based on the fault of the lab making spectacles.
useAndContext: Monitors access to eye care services
inclusions: INCLUDE all spectacles ordered i.e. ready made and custom made spectacles for adults 19 years and above.
exclusions: EXCLUDE re-ordered spectacles due to 1st pair not working for the client

name: Spectacles required by child - total
definition: Spectacles (ordered) required for clients age 7-18 years of age
definitionExtended: This should exclude re-orders based on the fault of the lab making spectacles.
useAndContext: Monitors access to eye care services
inclusions: INCLUDE all spectacles ordered i.e. ready made and custom made spectacles for children aged 7-18 years.
exclusions: EXCLUDE re-ordered spectacles due to 1st pair not working for the client

name: All HIV positive clients on ART eligible for TPT
definition: All HIV positive clients on ART eligible for TPT
definitionExtended: Includes all HIV positive clients who are on Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) and are eligible for TB Preventive Therapy (TPT)
useAndContext: This data element monitors the eligibility of HIV positive clients on ART for TB Preventive Therapy (TPT). It includes all HIV positive clients who are currently on ART and have been determined to be eligible for TPT. Clients who are HIV negative or who are HIV positive but not yet on ART are excluded from this data element
inclusions: INCLUDE All HIV-positive individuals who:

name: All HIV positive clients on ART, initiated on TPT
definition: Number of HIV-positive clients currently on antiretroviral therapy (ART) who were newly initiated on tuberculosis preventive therapy (TPT) within a specified reporting period
definitionExtended: This data element represents the total count of HIV-positive individuals, who are actively receiving ART, who started a course of TPT (tuberculosis preventive therapy) for the first time during the defined reporting period. This excludes clients who may have been on TPT previously
useAndContext: This data element tracks the implementation of TB preventive therapy among HIV-positive individuals on ART, a crucial component of integrated HIV and TB care. It helps monitor the progress towards TB prevention goals and identify areas where TPT initiation needs to be strengthened. It is an important indicator for program monitoring and evaluation at the facility, provincial, national and international level. It informs resource allocation and strategy development for both TB and HIV services
inclusions: INCLUDE Clients with a confirmed HIV-positive diagnosis

name: CD4 done on newly diagnosed HIV client
definition: CD4 test done on newly diagnosed HIV client
definitionExtended: Count only the first CD4 test done on newly diagnosed HIV client
useAndContext: This data element refers only to CD4 tests done on newly diagnosed HIV positive clients in the facility to monitor linkage to care
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register or TIER.Net

name: Female condoms distributed
definition: Female condoms distributed from a primary distribution site to health facilities or points in the community (e.g. campaigns, non-traditional outlets, etc.)
definitionExtended: Monitors distribution of female condoms for prevention of HIV and other STIs, and for contraceptive purposes. In some cases the primary distribution site might be at a hospital. The designated primary distribution points will be registered as separate facilities in the DHIS
useAndContext: Monitors distribution of female condoms for prevention of HIV and other STIs, and for contraceptive purposes.

name: HIV positive 15-24 years female (excl ANC)
definition: HIV test positive females in the 15-24 year age group (excluding antenatal)
definitionExtended: Includes only the first positive HIV test  within the reporting period
useAndContext: Monitors the impact of the HIV pandemic to assist in planning for effective strategies in combating HIV and AIDS
inclusions: INCLUDE First-time positive HIV test results for females aged 15-24 outside of ANC
exclusions: EXCLUDE Antenatal clients

name: HIV positive 15-24 years male
definition: HIV test positive males in the 15-24 year age group
definitionExtended: Includes only the first positive HIV test within the reporting period.
useAndContext: Monitors the impact of the HIV pandemic to assist in planning for effective strategies in combating HIV and AIDS
inclusions: INCLUDE First-time positive HIV test results for males aged 15-24
exclusions: EXCLUDE Antenatal clients

name: HIV positive 25-49 years (excl ANC)
definition: HIV test positive in the 25-49 year age group (excluding antenatal)
definitionExtended: Includes only the first positive HIV test within the reporting period.
useAndContext: Monitors the impact of the HIV pandemic to assist in planning for effective strategies in combating HIV and AIDS
inclusions: INCLUDE First-time positive HIV test results for individuals aged 25-49 outside of ANC
exclusions: EXCLUDE Antenatal clients

name: HIV positive 5-14 years (excl ANC)
definition: HIV test positive in the 5-14 year age group (excluding antenatal)
definitionExtended: Includes only the first positive HIV test within the reporting period.
useAndContext: Monitors the impact of the HIV pandemic on children to assist in planning for effective strategies in combating HIV and AIDS
inclusions: INCLUDE First-time positive HIV test results for children aged 5-14 outside of ANC
exclusions: EXCLUDE Antenatal clients

name: HIV positive 50 years and older
definition: HIV test positive in clients 50 years and older (excluding antenatal)
definitionExtended: Includes only the first positive HIV test  within the reporting period.
useAndContext: Monitors the impact of the HIV pandemic to assist in planning for effective strategies in combating HIV and AIDS
inclusions: INCLUDE First-time positive HIV test results for individuals aged 50 and older.
exclusions: EXCLUDE repeat tests on the same client to confirm diagnosis

name: HIV positive known but NOT on ART
definition: Clients with known HIV positive status but not on ART. In the absence of documented proof, HIV testing should be done as required by guidelines and a CD4 count test must be done.
definitionExtended: Patients who were never initiated on ART
useAndContext: Monitors HIV clients on ART
inclusions: INCLUDE Individuals with documented HIV-positive status, confirmed by testing if necessary
exclusions: EXCLUDE Individuals currently receiving ART

name: HIV positive screened for TB
definition: Number of HIV-positive clients screened for TB during a defined period
definitionExtended: This data element captures the count of HIV-positive individuals who have undergone TB screening during any healthcare visit. Screening involves asking specific questions and/or performing a physical examination to identify individuals who may be at risk for active TB or have presumptive TB. This data element is critical for monitoring adherence to clinical guidelines and ensuring timely identification of TB in people living with HIV (PLHIV)
useAndContext: This data element is used to track the implementation of national guidelines (e.g., ART (2023) and TB (2014) Clinical Guidelines) that mandate TB screening for all PLHIV at every clinical encounter. TB is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality among PLHIV, making routine screening essential for early detection and prompt initiation of preventative or treatment protocols. Data from this element is used to:

name: HIV test 15-24 years female (excl ANC)
definition: HIV rapid tests done in females in the 15-24 year age group
definitionExtended: Includes all rapid HIV tests performed within the specified criteria, regardless of the result.
useAndContext: Monitors HIV counselling and testing services among youth 15 to 24 years
exclusions: EXCLUDE Antenatal clients

name: HIV test 15-24 years male
definition: HIV rapid tests done in males in the 15-24 year age group
definitionExtended: Includes all rapid HIV tests performed within the specified criteria, regardless of the result.
useAndContext: Monitors HIV counselling and testing services among youth 15 to 24 years
exclusions: EXCLUDE Antenatal clients

name: HIV test 18-24 months
definition: Number of children aged 18-24 months who receive an HIV antibody test (rapid or standard)
definitionExtended: This data element tracks the number of children aged 18-24 months undergoing HIV antibody testing. This is critical for monitoring HIV transmission rates and ensuring early identification and linkage to care and treatment for HIV-positive children. The data informs program planning and quality improvement efforts related to pediatric HIV services
useAndContext: This data element is used to monitor the implementation of HIV testing policies and guidelines for infants and young children. It helps healthcare providers track the number of children who receive an HIV test between 18-24 months of age and identify any gaps or barriers to accessing HIV testing services
inclusions: INCLUDE All  HIV test results from rapid antibody tests conducted between 18-24 months of age
exclusions: EXCLUDE Confirmatory HIV test results

name: HIV test 25-49 years (excl ANC)
definition: HIV rapid tests done in the 25-49 year age group (excluding antenatal)
definitionExtended: Includes all rapid HIV tests performed within the specified criteria, regardless of the result
useAndContext: Monitors HIV counselling and testing services among adults 25 to 49 years
exclusions: EXCLUDE Antenatal clients

name: HIV test 5-14 years (excl ANC)
definition: HIV rapid tests done in the 5-14 year age group (excluding antenatal)
definitionExtended: Includes all rapid HIV tests performed within the specified criteria, regardless of the result
useAndContext: Monitors HIV counselling and testing services for children
exclusions: EXCLUDE Antenatal clients

name: HIV test 50 years and older
definition: HIV rapid tests done on clients 50 years and older (excluding antenatal)
definitionExtended: Includes all rapid HIV tests performed within the specified criteria, regardless of the result
useAndContext: Monitors HIV counselling and testing services among adults 50 years and older
exclusions: EXCLUDE repeat tests on the same client to confirm diagnosis

name: Male condoms distributed
definition: Male condoms distributed from a primary distribution site to health facilities or points in the community (e.g. campaigns, non-traditional outlets, etc.)
definitionExtended: Monitors distribution of male condoms for prevention of HIV and other STIs, and for contraceptive purposes. Note that research indicates only around 60% of distributed condoms are used for the intended purpose. In some cases the primary distribution site might be at a hospital. The designated primary distribution points will be registered as separate facilities in the DHIS
useAndContext: Monitors distribution of male condoms for prevention of HIV and other STIs, and for contraceptive purposes.

name: Medical male circumcision 10-14 years
definition: Males 10 to 14 years who are circumcised under medical supervision at healthcare facilities including mobile facilities
definitionExtended: Includes circumcisions performed using surgical methods (e.g., dorsal slit, forceps-guided).

name: Medical male circumcision 15 years and older
definition: Males 15 years and older who are circumcised under medical supervision at healthcare facilities including mobile facilities
definitionExtended: Record all males who are circumcised under medical supervision
useAndContext: Monitors medical male circumcisions 15 years and older performed
inclusions: INCLUDE medical male circumcisions done by private practitioners and NGOs
exclusions: EXCLUDE Male circumcision performed in the traditional sector
collectionPoints: Facilities where male circumcisions are performed

name: New sexual offence case HIV negative issued with Post Exposure Prophylaxis
definition: This data element captures the number of new individuals presenting for care following a sexual offence, testing HIV negative, and subsequently initiated on Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP). This includes individuals of all ages and genders
definitionExtended: This data element monitors the provision of post-exposure prophylaxis to sexual offence victims who have tested negative for HIV. This information can help improve the management and treatment of sexual offence cases and prevent the spread of HIV
useAndContext: This data element can help inform policies and interventions related to sexual offence prevention, response, and treatment. It can also help track the effectiveness of PEP administration and identify potential areas for improvement
inclusions: INCLUDE:

name: New sexual offence case seen at health facility
definition: Sexual offence encompass a range of acts to which consent has not been given and is usually accompanied by emotional or physical violence. Male and female sexual  offence  cases
definitionExtended: This data element captures the count of individuals who have experienced a recent incident of sexual offence (including but not limited to rape, sexual violence, sexual harassment, or sexual coercion) and are presenting at the health facility for the first time for assessment, medical treatment, or support related to this incident. This includes cases where an individual reports they did not consent to sexual activity and is seeking care. This include new case, reported unwanted sexual contact, reported sexual violence, sexual coercion, reported sexual sexual exploitation and all the genders
useAndContext: This data element helps to monitor the incidence of sexual offence and access to care, identify trends over time, inform resource allocation for care and support services, and evaluate the effectiveness of prevention and response programs. This data can indirectly support HIV programming with regard to Post Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) provision
inclusions: INCLUDE:

name: Accident and Emergency (Casualty) and Trauma unit headcount - Emergency
shortname: Accident and Emergency (Casualty) and Trauma unit headcount - Emergency
definition: All clients attending the Accident and Emergency (Casualty) and Trauma unit in a facility with conditions requiring emergency treatment only
definitionExtended: A medical emergency is an injury or illness that is acute and poses an immediate risk to a person`s life or long term health. Do not count non-emergency cases(cold cases) that attend the Casualty department after hours when OPD is closed. Non-emergency cases should be counted as part of the Casualty-non-emergency data elements (new cases with or without referral letters or follow-up cases). Typical examples of emergency are strokes, cardiac arrests, drowning, poisoning, clients in shock, children with high fever, asthma attacks, assaults, gunshots, motor vehicle accidents, rape cases and others. Emergency treatment is given to stabilize the client, where after the patient will usually be admitted for further treatment. A patient in the Accident and emergency unit who requires inpatient care, as determined and instructed by the clinician (i.e. Clinician instruction to admit at current or referral hospital), while waiting for a bed in the admission ward or a bed in the referral hospital should be counted as an emergency visit AND  registered and counted as an inpatient (against the appropriate admissions discipline/specialty), irrespective of where the patient is accommodated and whether they are accommodated in a bed or not, even i.e. if the patient is accommodated at Accident and Emergency unit in a bed, chair, trolley, floor etc. All non-emergency (cold cases) seen in Casualty unit should not be counted.
useAndContext: Weighted data element as proxy for estimating resources for all types of patients in terms of inpatient days
inclusions: INCLUDE only emergency cases
exclusions: EXCLUDE non-emergency cases
tools: Accident and Emergency unit (Casualty) and Trauma unit register

name: Accident and Emergency (Casualty) unit headcount - non-Emergency
shortname: Accident and Emergency (Casualty) unit headcount - non-Emergency
definition: All clients attending the Accident and Emergency unit (Casualty) in a facility with conditions requiring non-emergency  treatment
definitionExtended: A medical emergency is an injury or illness that is acute and poses an immediate risk to a person's life or long term health. Count non-emergency cases that attend the Casualty department after hours when OPD is closed. Non-emergency cases should be counted as part pf the Casualty-non-emergency data elements (all the OPD cases without referral letter. All assessments of pregnant women to determine progression of labour must be registered if patient presents at Casualty. All non-emergency (cold cases) seen in Casualty unit should be counted. All assessments of pregnant women to determine progression of labour must be registered if patient presents at Casualty .
useAndContext: Weighted data element as proxy for estimating resources for all types of patients in terms of inpatient days
inclusions: include all non-emergency (cold) cases. All assessments of pregnant women to determine progression of labour must be registered as a casualty unit if patient presents at Casualty .
exclusions: EXCLUDE emergency cases. Exclude assessments of pregnant women to determine progression of labour must not be registered at casualty unit if patient presents directly at Labour unit .
tools: Accident and Emergency unit (Casualty) and Trauma unit register

name: Day patient - Gynaecology
definition: An Gynaecology inpatient admitted and separated on the same calendar day
definitionExtended: Gynaecology: Investigates and treats problems relating to the female urinary tract and reproductive organs. These patients do not occupy a bed at midnight. Record all day patients also under the relevant separation data element: `Inpatient discharges-all`, `Inpatient deaths-all`, or `Inpatient transferred out - all`. Count as a Gynaecology day patient regardless of the sub-category of bed the patient occupy, e.g. if there is an overflow of one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a day patient for the sub-category they were admitted for.
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
inclusions: The total includes NIDS specialities plus all others that do not appear on the NIDS specialities

name: Day patient - Maternity
definition: A maternity inpatient admitted and separated on the same calendar day
definitionExtended: Maternity: Provides antenatal care, delivery of babies and care during childbirth, and postnatal support. These patients do not occupy a bed at midnight. Record all day patients also under the relevant separation data element: `Inpatient discharges-all`, `Inpatient deaths-all`, or `Inpatient transferred out - all`. Count as a Maternity day patient regardless of the sub-category of bed the patient occupy,  e.g. if there is an overflow of one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a day patient for the sub-category they were admitted for
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
inclusions: INCLUDE patients treated in the emergency unit who are held in the casualty/ emergency unit or elsewhere while waiting for a bed. The patients should be admitted based on the condition of the patient as determined by the treating doctor;

name: Day patient - Medicine
definition: A medicine inpatient admitted and separated on the same calendar day
definitionExtended: Medicine: The diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of disease excluding surgery. Day patient-Medicine includes TB. Count as a Medicine day patient regardless of the sub-category of bed the patient occupy, e.g. if there is an overflow of one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a day patient for the sub-category they were admitted for
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
inclusions: INCLUDE patients treated in the emergency unit who are held in the casualty/ emergency unit or elsewhere while waiting for a bed. The patients should be admitted based on the condition of the patient as determined by the treating doctor;

name: Day patient - Orthopaedic
definition: A Orthopaedic surgery inpatient admitted and separated on the same calendar day
definitionExtended: Orthopaedic: Treats conditions related to the musculoskeletal system, including joints, ligaments, bones, muscles, tendons and nerves. These patients do not occupy a bed at midnight. Record all day patients also under the relevant separation data element: `Inpatient discharges-all`, `Inpatient deaths-all`, or `Inpatient transferred out - all`. Count as a Orthopaedic day patient regardless of the sub-category of bed the patient occupy,  e.g. if there is an overflow of one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a day patient for the sub-category they were admitted for
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
inclusions: INCLUDE orthopaedic patients admitted intentionally for a day procedure and some medical patients;

name: Day patient - Paediatric
definition: A paediatric inpatient admitted and separated on the same calendar day. Paediatric day patients includes all children under 13 years irrespective of specialities.
definitionExtended: Paediatric: The medical care of infants and children under 13 years of age. These patients do not occupy a bed at midnight. Record all day patients also under the relevant separation data element: `Inpatient discharges-all`, `Inpatient deaths-all`, or `Inpatient transferred out - all`. Count as a Paediatric day patient regardless of the sub-category of bed the patient occupy, e.g. if there is an overflow of one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a day patient for the sub-category they were admitted for.
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
inclusions: INCLUDE all disciplines of Paediatric except for ICU INCLUDE children under 13 years admitted intentionally for a day procedure and some medical patients;

name: Day patient - Psychiatry
definition: A Psychiatric inpatient admitted and separated on the same calendar day
definitionExtended: Psychiatry: The diagnosis, prevention, study, and treatment of mental disorders. These patients do not occupy a bed at midnight. Record all day patients also under the relevant separation data element: `Inpatient discharges-all`, `Inpatient deaths-all`, or `Inpatient transferred out - all`. Count as a Psychiatry day patient regardless of the sub-category of bed the patient occupy, e.g. if there is an overflow of one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a day patient for the sub-category they were admitted for.
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
inclusions: INCLUDE patients treated in the emergency unit who are held in the casualty/ emergency unit or elsewhere while waiting for a bed. The patients should be admitted based on the condition of the patient as determined by the treating doctor;

name: Day patient - Surgery
definition: A surgical inpatient admitted and separated on the same calendar day
definitionExtended: Surgery: Patients are prepared for surgical procedures, where post-surgical care is provided as well as care of patients with surgical conditions that are treated by surgeons. These patients do not occupy a bed at midnight. Record all day patients also under the relevant separation data element: `Inpatient discharges-all`, `Inpatient deaths-all`, or `Inpatient transferred out - all`. Count as a Surgery day patient regardless of the sub-category of bed the patient occupy, e.g. if there is an overflow of one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a day patient for the sub-category they were admitted for.
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
inclusions: INCLUDE surgical patients admitted intentionally for a day procedure and some medical patients;

name: Day patient - total
definition: The total count of inpatients admitted in hospitals and CHC/CDC and separated on the same calendar day.
definitionExtended: These patients do not occupy a bed at midnight.
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
inclusions: INCLUDE surgical patients admitted intentionally for a day procedure and some medical patients;

name: Dead on arrival
definition: A patient who is certified dead on arrival
definitionExtended: Patient who is certified dead on arrival at facility before any resuscitation is attempted. Count as a death on arrival if no intervention by facility health professionals
useAndContext: To facilitate registration of death with Home Affairs. Death registration assist in compiling accurate, complete, and timely vital statistics, which, along with population censuses, are central to estimating population size.
inclusions: INCLUDE as death if patient died in transit by EMS;

name: Expenditure - total
definition: Total expenditure for the facility
definitionExtended: Obtain from financial manager who should extract it from BAS
useAndContext: To quantify the total expenditure for the facility

name: Hospital public
definition: A hospital in the public sector that is classified according to the Government Gazette as a District Hospital, Regional Hospital, Tertiary Hospital, Central Hospital or Specialised Hospital
useAndContext: This semi-permanent data element will have the value 1 for each Hospital that fulfils the criteria

name: Inpatient beds - Gynaecology
definition: Inpatient beds-Gynaecology is a subcategory of inpatient beds that are approved for use within the health facility. Hospitals should use their routine data to determine the number of beds needed for Gynaecology patients. This is a semi-permanent data element that should only be revised on an annual basis if there's a change in the need for Gynaecology beds.
definitionExtended: Gynaecology: Investigates and treats problems relating to the female urinary tract and reproductive organs. A bed is a unit of accommodation in a health facility. A bed is used for admitting patients. An admission is a patient who undergoes the hospital formal admission process for either a patient or a day patient because they require inpatient care that cannot be administered on an outpatient basis. A bed is used for an admitted client and not for a boarder (e.g. kangaroo mothers), a well-baby, a client undergoing a procedure (e.g. in theatre) or an outpatient undergoing procedures, examinations or resuscitation. Hospitals with an inpatient bed sub-category of Gynaecology must also report inpatient days, day patients, inpatient discharges and inpatient transfers for the sub-category of Gynaecology.
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
exclusions: EXCLUDE delivery beds, surgical tables, recovery trolleys, stretchers, chairs and recliners (e.g. as used for renal dialysis patients etc.)

name: Inpatient beds - High Care
definition: Inpatient beds-High Care is a subcategory of inpatient beds that are approved for use within the health facility. Hospitals should use their routine data to determine the number of beds needed for high care patients. This is a semi-permanent data element that should only be revised on an annual basis if there's a change in the need for high care beds.
definitionExtended: High Care: is a special department in a hospital where patients that require close observation and monitoring, are cared for. A bed is a unit of accommodation in a health facility. A bed is used for admitting patients. An admission is a patient who undergoes the hospital formal admission process for either a patient or a day patient because they require inpatient care that cannot be administered on an outpatient basis. A bed is used for an admitted client and not for a boarder (e.g. kangaroo mothers), a well-baby, a client undergoing a procedure (e.g. in theatre) or an outpatient undergoing procedures, examinations or resuscitation. Hospitals with an inpatient bed subcategory of High Care must also report inpatient days, day patients, inpatient discharges and inpatient transfers for the subcategory of High Care.
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
inclusions: Includes all disciplines of High Care
exclusions: EXCLUDE surgical tables, recovery trolleys, stretchers, chairs and recliners (e.g. as used for renal dialysis patients etc.)

name: Inpatient beds - ICU
definition: Inpatient beds - ICU is a subcategory of inpatient beds that are approved for use within the health facility. Hospitals should use their routine data to determine the number of beds needed for ICU patients. This is a semi-permanent data element that should only be revised on an annual basis if there's a change in the need for ICU beds.
definitionExtended: Intensive Care: is a special department in a hospital where seriously ill patients, that require close observation and monitoring, are cared for by specially trained staff that provides intensive treatment for patients requiring advanced respiratory support, support of two or more failing organ systems or treatment of life threatening infections. A bed is a unit of accommodation in a health facility. A bed is used for admitting patients. An admission is a patient who undergoes the hospital formal admission process for either a patient or a day patient because they require inpatient care that cannot be administered on an outpatient basis. A bed is used for an admitted client and not for a boarder (e.g. kangaroo mothers), a well-baby, a client undergoing a procedure (e.g. in theatre) or an outpatient undergoing procedures, examinations or resuscitation. Hospitals with an inpatient bed sub-category of ICU must also report inpatient days, day patients, inpatient discharges and inpatient transfers for the sub-category of ICU.
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
inclusions: Includes all disciplines of ICU
exclusions: EXCLUDE surgical tables, recovery trolleys, stretchers, chairs and recliners (e.g. as used for renal dialysis patients etc.)

name: Inpatient beds - Maternity
definition: Inpatient beds-Maternity is a subcategory of inpatient beds that are approved for use within the health facility. Hospitals should use their routine data to determine the number of beds needed for Maternity patients. This is a semi-permanent data element that should only be revised on an annual basis if there's a change in the need for Maternity beds.
definitionExtended: Maternity: Provides antenatal care, delivery of babies and care during childbirth, and postnatal support. A bed is a unit of accommodation in a health facility. A bed is used for admitting patients. An admission is a patient who undergoes the hospital formal admission process for either a patient or a day patient because they require inpatient care that cannot be administered on an outpatient basis. A bed is used for an admitted client and not for a boarder (e.g. kangaroo mothers), a well-baby, a client undergoing a procedure (e.g. in theatre) or an outpatient undergoing procedures, examinations or resuscitation. Hospitals with an inpatient bed sub-category of Maternity must also report inpatient days, day patients, inpatient discharges and inpatient transfers for the sub-category of Maternity.
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
inclusions: Include: MOUs (CHC/ CDC)
exclusions: EXCLUDE delivery beds, surgical tables, recovery trolleys, stretchers, chairs and recliners (e.g. as used for renal dialysis patients etc.)

name: Inpatient beds - Medicine
definition: Inpatient beds-Medicine is a subcategory of inpatient beds that are approved for use within the health facility. Hospitals should use their routine data to determine the number of beds needed for Medicine patients. This is a semi-permanent data element that should only be revised on an annual basis if there's a change in the need for Medicine beds.
definitionExtended: Medicine: The diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of disease excluding surgery. A bed is a unit of accommodation in a health facility. A bed is used for admitting patients. An admission is a patient who undergoes the hospital formal admission process for either a patient or a day patient because they require inpatient care that cannot be administered on an outpatient basis. A bed is used for an admitted client and not for a boarder (e.g. kangaroo mothers), a well-baby, a client undergoing a procedure (e.g. in theatre) or an outpatient undergoing procedures, examinations or resuscitation. Hospitals with an inpatient bed sub-category of Medicine must also report inpatient days, day patients, inpatient discharges and inpatient transfers for the sub-category of Medicine.
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
inclusions: INCLUDE beds for TB cases
exclusions: EXCLUDE delivery beds, surgical tables, recovery trolleys, cots for normal neonates (well baby cots), stretchers, chairs and recliners (e.g. as used for renal dialysis patients etc.)

name: Inpatient beds - Neonatal High Care
definition: Inpatient beds-Neonatal High Care is a subcategory of inpatient beds that are approved for use within the health facility. Hospitals should use their routine data to determine the number of beds needed for Neonatal High Care patients. This is a semi-permanent data element that should only be revised on an annual basis if there's a change in the need for Neonatal High Care beds.
definitionExtended: Neonatal High Care: Closely linked with the hospital maternity department, provides care and support for babies who need close observation or monitoring than cannot safely be provided in a maternity ward. A bed is a unit of accommodation in a health facility. A bed is used for admitting patients. An admission is a patient who undergoes the hospital formal admission process for either a patient or a day patient because they require inpatient care that cannot be administered on an outpatient basis. A bed is used for an admitted client and not for a boarder (e.g. kangaroo mothers), a well-baby, a client undergoing a procedure (e.g. in theatre) or an outpatient undergoing procedures, examinations or resuscitation. Hospitals with an inpatient bed sub-category of Neonatal High Care must also report inpatient days, day patients, inpatient discharges and inpatient transfers for the sub-category of Neonatal High Care. This is a subset of Inpatient Beds - Paediatrics.
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
exclusions: EXCLUDE surgical tables, recovery trolleys, cots for normal neonates (well baby cots)

name: Inpatient beds - Neonatal ICU
definition: Inpatient beds-Neonatal ICU is a subcategory of inpatient beds that are approved for use within the health facility. Hospitals should use their routine data to determine the number of beds needed for Neonatal ICU patients. This is a semi-permanent data element that should only be revised on an annual basis if there's a change in the need for Neonatal ICU beds.
definitionExtended: Neonatal ICU: Closely linked with the hospital maternity department, provides critical care for newborn babies that needs advanced life support. A bed is a unit of accommodation in a health facility. A bed is used for admitting patients. An admission is a patient who undergoes the hospital formal admission process for either a patient or a day patient because they require inpatient care that cannot be administered on an outpatient basis. A bed is used for an admitted client and not for a boarder (e.g. kangaroo mothers), a well-baby, a client undergoing a procedure (e.g. in theatre) or an outpatient undergoing procedures, examinations or resuscitation. Hospitals with an inpatient bed sub-category of Neonatal ICU must also report inpatient days, day patients, inpatient discharges and inpatient transfers for the sub-category of Neonatal ICU.This is a subset of Inpatient beds - Total; and of Inpatient beds - ICU
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
exclusions: EXCLUDE delivery beds, surgical tables, recovery trolleys, cots for normal neonates (well baby cots), stretchers, chairs and recliners (e.g. as used for renal dialysis patients etc.)

name: Inpatient beds - Neonatal Standard Inpatient Care
definition: Inpatient beds - Standard sick neonate (NSIC)is a subcategory of inpatient beds that are approved for use within the health facility. The number of inpatient beds should include neonatal beds in Kangaroo Mother Care units. This includes admissions of neonates in Kangaroo Mother Care unit in nurseries, paediatric wards as well as postnatal wards where there are no neonatal units for sick neonates
definitionExtended: Hospitals should use their routine data to determine the number of beds needed for Neonatal sick inpatients. This is a semi-permanent data element that should only be revised on an annual basis if there is a change in the need for Neonatal sick inpatient beds. This is a subset of Inpatient Beds - Paediatrics

name: Inpatient beds approved - total
definition: Number of approved inpatient beds for the health facility. The number of approved beds is a semi permanent data element. Any increase or decrease must be motivated and can only be done through the office of the HOD and National Department of Health should be informed when such changes occur.
definitionExtended: A bed is a unit of accommodation in a health facility. A bed is used for admitting patients. An admission is a patient who undergoes the hospital formal admission process for either a patient or a day patient because they require inpatient care that cannot be administered on an outpatient basis. A bed is used for an admitted client and not for a boarder (e.g. kangaroo mothers), a well-baby, a client undergoing a procedure (e.g. in theatre) or an outpatient undergoing procedures, examinations or resuscitation.
