Please note that this is a semi permanent data element that should only be revised and captured on an annual basis. Any increase or decrease must be motivated and can only be done through the office of the HOD and National Department of Health should be informed when such changes occur.

name: Inpatient death - Gynaecology
definition: An inpatient death Gynaecology is a death recorded against an admitted gynae and obstetric inpatient, including the death of a patient admitted earlier on the same day
definitionExtended: Gynaecology: Investigates and treats problems relating to the female urinary tract and reproductive organs. Count any death of an inpatient, even if the cause of death does not directly relate to the cause of admission or the specialty of the ward. For instance, a death due to an accident or an act of violence must be counted. Count as a Gynaecology Inpatient death regardless of the sub-category of bed the patient occupy when the death occurs, e.g. when there is an overflow of one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a inpatient death for the sub-category they were admitted for.
useAndContext: Monitors trends in Inpatient deaths. Provides an indication of the quality of Inpatient care
exclusions: EXCLUDE dead on arrivals

name: Inpatient discharge - Gynaecology
definition: An inpatient discharge Gynaecology is a Gynaecology patient admitted to a ward that completes an inpatient stay and is discharged to their usual residence including home, family, correctional centre, hostel etc.-including the discharge of a patient on the same day of admission
definitionExtended: Gynaecology: Investigates and treats problems relating to the female urinary tract and reproductive organs. Avoid using admissions as a proxy for discharges, except as a last resort. Count as a Gynaecology Inpatient discharge regardless of the sub-category of bed the patient occupied during the hospital stay-for e.g. if there is an overflow of one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a inpatient discharge for the sub-category they were admitted for.
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
inclusions: INCLUDE self-discharges (client absconding and refusal of hospital treatment)

Count as a High Care Inpatient discharge regardless of the sub-category of bed the patient occupied during the hospital stay-for e.g. if there is an overflow of one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a inpatient discharge for the sub-category they were admitted for. inclusions: INCLUDE all disciplines of high care

Count as a Medicine Inpatient discharge regardless of the sub-category of bed the patient occupied during the hospital stay, e.g. if there is an overflow of one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a inpatient discharge for the sub-category they were admitted for.
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
inclusions: INCLUDE self-discharges (client absconding and refusal of hospital treatment)

name: Inpatient discharge - Neonatal High Care

useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
exclusions: EXCLUDE deaths

name: Inpatient discharge - Neonatal Standard Inpatient Care

Count as a Neonatal High Care Inpatient discharge regardless of the sub-category of bed the patient occupied during the hospital stay, e.g. if there is an overflow of one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a inpatient discharge for the sub-category they were admitted for. inclusions: INCLUDE self-discharges (client absconding and refusal of hospital treatment)

name: Inpatient discharges - total
definition: An inpatient discharge is a patient admitted to a ward that completes an inpatient stay and is discharged to their usual residence including home, family, correctional centre, hostel etc.-including the discharge of a patient on the same day of admission. The total is specialities plus all others that do not appear on the identified specialities.
definitionExtended: Avoid using admissions as a proxy for discharges, except as a last resort. Note that while there might seem to be a fine line between sub-acute facilities, frail care centres, and old age homes, the difference lies in the term `discharged to their usual residence`.

name: Inpatient separations - Neonatal

definitionExtended: Inpatient deaths - Neonatal + inpatient discharges - Neonatal + inpatient transfers out - Neonatal
useAndContext: To quantify the total neonatal separations

name: Inpatient transfer out - Gynaecology

definitionExtended: Gynaecology: Investigates and treats problems relating to the female urinary tract and reproductive organs. Patients are directed or physically transferred to another hospital, maternity obstetric unit (MOU) with inpatient facilities or Sub-acute facility for immediate admission there. Count as an Gynaecology Inpatient transfer out regardless of the sub-category of bed the patient occupied before the transfer,  e.g. if there is an overflow of one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a inpatient transfer out for the sub-category they were admitted for
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
inclusions: INCLUDE patients transferred out to another public or private hospital or sub-acute facility

name: Inpatient transfer out - High Care
definition: Admitted high care patients who were transferred to another hospital for immediate admission there, including the transfer out of a patient admitted earlier on the same day
definitionExtended: High Care: provides care and support for patients who need close observation or monitoring than cannot safely be provided in a normal ward. Patients are directed or physically transferred to another hospital or Sub-acute facility for immediate admission there. Count as a High Care Inpatient transfer out regardless of the sub-category of bed the patient occupied before the transfer, e.g. if there is an overflow of one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a inpatient transfer out for the sub-category they were admitted for. This is a subset of Inpatient transfer out - Total; and of all disciplines except ICU

name: Inpatient transfer out - ICU

definitionExtended: Intensive Care: is a special department in a hospital where seriously ill patients, that require close observation and monitoring, are cared for by specially trained staff that provides intensive treatment for patients requiring advanced respiratory support, support of two or more failing organ systems or treatment of life threatening infections. Patients are directed or physically transferred to another hospital or Sub-acute facility for immediate admission there. Count as an ICU inpatient transfer out regardless of the sub-category of bed the patient occupied before the transfer,  e.g. if there is an overflow of one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a inpatient transfer out for the sub-category they were admitted for
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
inclusions: INCLUDE all disciplines of ICU

useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
inclusions: INCLUDE NIDS specialities plus all others that do not appear on the NIDS specialities

name: OPD headcount follow-up
definition: Client attending a general or specialist Outpatient clinic for follow-up care
definitionExtended: This would include visits to Service Groups like Physiotherapist, Dietician, X-rays, etc., as well as previous ward attendees returning to the hospital for a check-up. Clients can be seen in the OPD section of the hospital. Count each client only once for the day irrespective of the number of services provided. All assessments of pregnant women to determine progression of labour must be registered as an OPD visit. The assessment may take place in the emergency centre or in a specific area and the facility should keep a register of the visits.

name: OPD headcount not referred new
definition: New clients attending a general or specialist Outpatient clinic WITHOUT a referral letter from a PHC facility or a doctor
definitionExtended: Clients must be seen in the OPD section of the hospital. Count each client only once for the day irrespective of the number of services provided. If there are arrangements in a facility to provide an outpatient service in a ward due to shortage of space, the facility should keep a register of the visits. Clients/patients seen in the OPD and then admitted should be recorded as an OPD visit as well as an admission. Outpatients transported by ambulance to another facility and requiring emergency attention at a facility en route must be recorded as an emergency visit en route
useAndContext: Monitors utilisation trends of clients by-passing PHC facilities and the effect of PHC re-engineering on OPD utilisation.
inclusions: INCLUDE telehealth visits conducted by a health care worker

name: OPD headcount referred new
definition: New client attending a general or specialist Outpatient clinic with a referral letter from a PHC facility or a doctor
definitionExtended: Clients can be seen in the OPD section of the hospital. Count each client only once for the day irrespective of the number of services provided. All assessments of pregnant women to determine progression of labour must be registered as an OPD visit. The assessment may take place in the emergency centre or in a specific area and the facility should keep a register of the visits.

name: Fixed CHC
definition: A fixed CHC that renders comprehensive integrated PHC services that is open 24 hours, 7 days per week, and Fixed CDC is open up to 12 hours per day.
useAndContext: This semi-permanent data element will have the value 1 for each CHC that fulfils the criteria

name: Fixed clinic
definition: An appropriately permanently equipped facility at which a range of Primary Health Care services are provided. It is open at least 8 hours a day at least 4 days a week
useAndContext: This semi-permanent data element will have the value 1 for each clinic that fulfils the criteria

name: PHC client seen by doctor (full time/sessional)
definition: A PHC client consulted and or treated by a doctor employed full time/sessional in the public sector to render general clinical services
definitionExtended: This data element should be collected in all PHC facilities with full time / sessional doctors. Clients might originally be seen by a professional nurse for a PHC service or may be seen directly by the doctor; Each client is counted every time they are seen by a doctor, even if a client is seen by more than one doctor per day or client visit facility more than once per day and seen by a doctor; ONLY clients seen for preventive, promotive and curative must be counted
useAndContext: Monitoring of services rendered by public full time / sessional doctors to consult PHC clients in public health facilities in accordance with the NHI objectives to increase doctor coverage
inclusions: INCLUDE patient seen for renewal of prescriptions
exclusions: EXCLUDE any facility that does not have Full Time/sessional  doctors

name: PHC client seen by professional nurse
definition: A PHC client of any age consulted and or treated by a professional nurse (PN) for a Primary Health Care service
definitionExtended: Any client seen by a Professional nurse should be counted. Each client is counted every time they are seen by a Professional Nurse, even if a client is seen by more than one PN per day or client visit facility more than once per day and seen by a PN
useAndContext: Monitor PN workload
inclusions: INCLUDE clients seen for preventative, promotive and curative services

name: PHC headcount 10-19 years
definition: Adolescents and youth 10-19 years old seen for Primary Health Care
definitionExtended: Count each client once for each day they appear at the facility, regardless of the number of services provided on that day; If the client is recorded as a headcount at the registration point, and the client then leaves the facility voluntarily without receiving the service that he or she is supposed to receive, a headcount can be recorded; Count all clients who access the facility for preventive, promotive, curative and rehabilitative services at a facility or with a chronic disease for whom medication is collected at the facility
useAndContext: Monitors PHC access and utilisation for clients 10-19 years
inclusions: INCLUDE cases where a client visits a facility to get feedback on any diagnostic tests done; INCLUDE clients whose medication was collected by a Home Community Based Care (HCBC worker or family member or friend as a headcount registered at the registration point; INCLUDE cases where a client visits a facility to submit sputum samples produced outside of the facility and or sputum samples produced at facility with assistance of health professional; INCLUDE a DOTS visit to the facility (but not to the community, workplace or home); INCLUDE clients who come to collect chronic medication dispensed by the facility itself (excluding CCMDD/ CDU medication) or clients using fast lines, or those to be seen by ADHERENCE counsellor at the facility; INCLUDE clients seen by a professional nurse appointed by a NPO and seconded to a clinic or service; INCLUDE clients who bypass the registration unit and go directly to the pharmacy to collect their own chronic medication or clients using fast lanes or those to be seen by outreach teams, or those to be seen by HIV counsellors; INCLUDE all clients on Space Fast Lane Modality (SFLA) who bypass registration
exclusions: EXCLUDE clients seen by health professionals of the facility part of an outreach team at another health facility; EXCLUDE national campaign headcounts;

name: PHC headcount 20 years and older
definition: All individual clients 20 years and older seen for Primary Health Care services at a facility
definitionExtended: Count each client once for each day they appear at the facility, regardless of the number of services provided on that day; If the client is recorded as a headcount at the registration point, and the client then leaves the facility voluntarily without receiving the service that he or she is supposed to receive, a headcount can be recorded; Count all clients who access the facility for preventive, promotive, curative and rehabilitative services at a facility or with a chronic disease for whom medication is collected at the facility
useAndContext: Monitors PHC access and utilisation for clients 20 years and older.
inclusions: INCLUDE cases where a client visits a facility to get feedback on any diagnostic tests done; INCLUDE clients whose medication was collected by a Home Community Based Care (HCBC worker or family member or friend as a headcount registered at the registration point; INCLUDE cases where a client visits a facility to submit sputum samples produced outside of the facility and or sputum samples produced at facility with assistance of health professional; INCLUDE a DOTS visit to the facility (but not to the community, workplace or home); INCLUDE clients who come to collect chronic medication dispensed by the facility itself (excluding CCMDD/ CDU medication) or clients using fast lines, or those to be seen by ADHERENCE counsellor at the facility; INCLUDE clients seen by a professional nurse appointed by a NPO and seconded to a clinic or service; INCLUDE clients who bypass the registration unit and go directly to the pharmacy to collect their own chronic medication or clients using fast lanes or those to be seen by outreach teams, or those to be seen by HIV counsellors; INCLUDE all clients on Space Fast Lane Modality (SFLA) who bypass registration
exclusions: EXCLUDE clients seen by health professionals of the facility part of an outreach team at another health facility; EXCLUDE national campaign headcounts;

name: PHC headcount 5-9 years
definition: All individual clients 5-9 years seen for Primary Health Care services at a facility
definitionExtended: Count each client once for each day they appear at the facility, regardless of the number of services provided on that day; If the client is recorded as a headcount at the registration point, and the client then leaves the facility voluntarily without receiving the service that he or she is supposed to receive, a headcount can be recorded; Count all clients who access the facility for preventive, promotive, curative and rehabilitative services at a facility or with a chronic disease for whom medication is collected at the facility
useAndContext: Monitors PHC access and utilisation for children 5-9 years.
inclusions: INCLUDE cases where a client visits a facility to get feedback on any diagnostic tests done; INCLUDE clients whose medication was collected by a Home Community Based Care (HCBC worker or family member or friend as a headcount registered at the registration point; INCLUDE cases where a client visits a facility to submit sputum samples produced outside of the facility and or sputum samples produced at facility with assistance of health professional; INCLUDE a DOTS visit to the facility (but not to the community, workplace or home); INCLUDE clients who come to collect chronic medication dispensed by the facility itself (excluding CCMDD/ CDU medication) or clients using fast lines, or those to be seen by ADHERENCE counsellor at the facility; INCLUDE clients seen by a professional nurse appointed by a NPO and seconded to a clinic or service; INCLUDE clients who bypass the registration unit and go directly to the pharmacy to collect their own chronic medication or clients using fast lanes or those to be seen by outreach teams, or those to be seen by HIV counsellors; INCLUDE all clients on Space Fast Lane Modality (SFLA) who bypass registration
exclusions: EXCLUDE children seen by health professionals of the facility part of an outreach team at another health facility; EXCLUDE national campaign (EPI or <5 years, HPV vaccination) headcounts;

name: PHC headcount under 5 years
definition: All individual clients not yet reached five years (60 months) seen for Primary Health Care services at a facility
definitionExtended: Count each client once for each day they appear at the facility, regardless of the number of services provided on that day. If the client is recorded as a headcount at the registration point and the client then leaves the facility voluntarily without receiving the service that he or she is supposed to receive, a headcount can be recorded. If infant is delivered at the facility, the infant should be countered as a headcount because services like immunisation, MUAC, PCR testing at birth and full baby examination, etc. are provided to that infant. Record only a sick child who is brought to the facility for treatment or a child with a chronic disease for whom medication is collected at the facility
useAndContext: Monitors PHC access and utilisation for children under 5 years.
inclusions: INCLUDE cases where a client visits a facility to get feedback on any diagnostic tests done; INCLUDE clients whose medication was collected by a Home Community Based Care (HCBC worker or family member or friend as a headcount registered at the registration point INCLUDE cases where a client visits a facility to submits sputum samples produced outside of the facility and or sputum samples produced at facility with assistance of health professional

name: PHC professional nurse clinical work days
definition: The actual work days by Professional Nurses used to perform clinical services
definitionExtended: Days spent on PHC clinical and normal daily administrative work related to client care, are counted. One actual work day is normally equivalent to an 8-hour shift (40 hours). Professional nurses can be full time or part time employed. Work day equivalents:

name: PHC public/sessional doctor clinical work days
definition: The actual work days by doctors employed in the public sector/sessional doctors employed on contract in the public sector rendering a general clinical service
definitionExtended: This figure should include ONLY clinical work (i.e. handling clients), including administrative record keeping related to clients; Work day equivalents:

name: Mental health involuntary admission
definition: Client admitted for mental health conditions in terms of section 33 of the Mental Health Care Act No 17 of 2002
definitionExtended: These are clients who are admitted and provided with care, treatment and rehabilitation without their informed consent and due to their mental health status are refusing/ unwilling to be admitted and receive the required care, treatment and rehabilitation. The data element should be collected at all hospitals with designated psychiatric beds or wards, specialised psychiatric hospitals and hospitals listed to provide the 72-hour assessment contemplated in section 34 of the Mental Health Care Act.  These admissions have to be monitored and controlled in view of the human rights issues risks associated
useAndContext: Monitors involuntary admissions in terms of the Mental Health Care Act 17 of 2002.
inclusions: INCLUDE clients that were originally admitted under section 9 (c) (emergency admission without consent) and section 40 (1) (handed over by members of the SAPS) of the Mental Health Care Act No 17 of 2002 as soon as an application for them is made in terms of Section 33 of the Mental Health Care Act, 2002

name: Mental health separations 18 years and older
definition: Client 18 years and older admitted for mental health conditions counted at separation
definitionExtended: Adults admitted for Mental health/psychiatry intervention, including counselling/psychotherapy for rape /sexual assault cases, substance abuse cases, physical abuse cases, behavioural problems in children and adolescents including those admitted for care, treatment and rehabilitation for mental disorders like neurodevelopmental disorders, psychosis disorders, depressive disorders, suicide attempts, trauma and stressor related disorders, eating disorders, substance related and addiction disorders, intellectual disability and neurocognitive disorders
useAndContext: Monitors inpatient mental health workload and integration of mental health in general hospitals.
inclusions: INCLUDE voluntary, involuntary, assisted mental health care users, state patients and mentally ill prisoners
exclusions: EXCLUDE children under 18 yrs
collectionPoints: Inpatient psychiatric units and wards with psychiatric beds in general hospitals

name: Mental health separations under 18 years
definition: Client under 18 years admitted for mental health conditions counted at separation
definitionExtended: Children admitted for Mental health/psychiatry intervention, including counselling/psychotherapy for rape /sexual assault cases, substance abuse cases, physical abuse cases, behavioural problems in children and adolescents including those admitted for care, treatment and rehabilitation for mental disorders like neurodevelopmental disorders, psychosis disorders, depressive disorders, suicide attempts, trauma and stressor related disorders, eating disorders, substance related and addiction disorders, intellectual disability and neurocognitive disorders
useAndContext: Monitors inpatient mental health workload and integration of mental health in general hospitals.
inclusions: INCLUDE voluntary, involuntary, assisted mental health care users, state patients and mentally ill prisoners
exclusions: EXCLUDE Adults (18yrs and older)
collectionPoints: Inpatient psychiatric units and wards with psychiatric beds in general hospitals

name: Patient Safety Incident case closed
definition: Patient Safety Incident (PSI) case closed within the reporting month
definitionExtended: Patient safety incident: is an event or circumstance that could have resulted, or did result, in unnecessary harm to a patient. The use of the word “unnecessary” in this definition recognizes that errors, violation, patient abuse and deliberately unsafe acts occur in healthcare. These are considered incidents. Incident: An incident can be a reportable circumstance, near miss, no harm incident or harmful incident (adverse event). Reportable circumstance: is a situation in which there was significant potential for harm, but no incident occurred. Near miss: is an incident which did not reach the patient. No harm incident: is one in which an event reached a patient but no discernible harm resulted. Harmful incident: is an incident that results in harm to a patient. Adverse event: harm related to medical management, in contrast to disease complications or underlying disease. Medical management includes all aspects of care from interaction with health care provider to discharge of a patient from medical treatment or health care facility.
useAndContext: Monitors the implementation of the National policy to manage patient safety incidents

name: Patient Safety Incident case closed within 60 days
definition: Patient Safety Incident (PSI) case closed within 60 days after being reported.
useAndContext: Monitors the implementation of the National policy to manage patient safety incidents

Incident: An incident can be a reportable circumstance, near miss, no harm incident or harmful incident (adverse event). Reportable circumstance: is a situation in which there was significant potential for harm, but no incident occurred. Near miss: is an incident which did not reach the patient. No harm incident: is one in which an event reached a patient but no discernible harm resulted. Harmful incident: is an incident that results in harm to a patient. Adverse event: harm related to medical management, in contrast to disease complications or underlying disease. Medical management includes all aspects of care from interaction with health care provider to discharge of a patient from medical treatment or health care facility.
useAndContext: Monitors the implementation of the National policy to manage patient safety incidents

useAndContext: Monitors the implementation of the National policy to manage patient safety incidents

name: All referrals from community health workers
definitionExtended: A pregnant woman diagnosed with syphilis during her current pregnancy who has received three intramuscular (IM) doses of 2.4 MU (million units) of benzathine penicillin G (BPG), administered approximately weekly with intervals not exceeding 14 days between doses. The third and final dose must have been administered at least 4 weeks (28 days) prior to her expected delivery date.
useAndContext: Syphilis treatment with BPG during pregnancy is crucial for preventing vertical transmission of syphilis and improving maternal and infant health outcomes. Consistent monitoring of BPG administration contributes directly to the goal of eliminating congenital syphilis.
inclusions: INCLUDE All pregnant women who initiated treatment for syphilis during their current pregnancy and completed all three required BPG doses meeting the specified criteria

name: Male urethritis syndrome 15-49 years treated - new episode

Newly developed symptoms and signs of MUS although the client may previously have had MUS: If a client received treatment for MUS and adhered to treatment and the MUS got resolved but comes again with similar symptoms due to re-exposure, then it means he presents with a new episode of MUS. One client can have more than one new episode.
useAndContext: Monitoring of MUS informs of sexual behaviour

inclusions: INCLUDE TB contacts (under 5yrs and 5yrs and older combined) for both DS and DR-TB

name: COS TB lost to follow up traced
definition: TB patients who are lost to follow and traced with an outcome for the visit recorded
definitionExtended: The community health worker (CHW) must enter the total number of clients referred to facility for TB services
useAndContext: Monitors implementation of PHC WBOT policy
inclusions: INCLUDE All TB patients traced who are listed in the TB lost to  follow-up list/register by facility for physical tracing in the household

name: COS Vitamin A dose 12-59 months
definition: Child from 12-59 months provided with Vitamin A in household by WBPHCOT
definitionExtended: The community health worker (CHW) must enter the total number of children 12-59 months provided with Vitamin A
useAndContext: Monitors implementation of Policy Framework and Strategy for WBPHCOT
inclusions: INCLUDE All children 12-59 months seen by WBPHCOT who received Vitamin A dose in the household and other community settings outside households

name: COS clients  18-44 years screened for hypertension
definition: Individual clients 18-44 years screened for hypertension
definitionExtended: This should assist with increasing the number of people detected and referred for treatment
useAndContext: Monitor the national health wellness and

name: COS clients 18-44 years screened for diabetes
definition: Individual clients 18-44 screened for  diabetes
definitionExtended: This should assist with increasing the number of people detected and referred for treatment
useAndContext: This should assist with increasing the number of people detected and referred for treatment

name: COS clients 45 years and older screened for diabetes
definition: Individual clients 45 years and above screened for diabetes
definitionExtended: This should assist with increasing the number of people detected and referred for treatment
useAndContext: This should assist with increasing the number of people detected and referred for treatment

name: COS clients 45 years and older screened for hypertension
definition: Individual clients 45 years and above screened for hypertension
definitionExtended: This should assist with increasing the number of people detected and referred for treatment
useAndContext: Monitor the national health wellness and healthy lifestyle campaigns to reduce the burden of disease and ill-health.

name: COS clients screened for mental health problems
definition: Individual clients screened by CHW for mental health problems
definitionExtended: The indicator will provide information on the demand and access to mental health at community level.
useAndContext: It will improve the quality of mental health care services and the number of people screened for mental health problems

name: COS clients with Adherence Support
definition: Outreach household visit where adherence support was provided  to households members or clients
definitionExtended: None   Count individual clients
useAndContext: Count individual clients

name: COS deworming dose 12-59 months
definition: Child from 12-59 months provided with deworming dose in household by WBPHCOT
definitionExtended: The community health worker (CHW) must enter the total number of children 12 - 59 months provided with deworming dose, on the CHW Daily activity tracker form
useAndContext: Monitors implementation of Policy Framework and Strategy for WBPHCOT
inclusions: INCLUDE All children 12-59 months seen by WBPHCOT who received deworming dose in household and other community settings outside households

name: COS headcount 10-19 years
definition: Individual client 10  to 19 years attended to by WBPHCOT in the households
definitionExtended: Count each client once for each day they are visited in the household, regardless of the number of services provided on that day
useAndContext: Monitors implementation of Policy Framework and Strategy for WBPHCOT
inclusions: INCLUDE All individual clients 10  to 19 years attended to by WBPHCOT in the households and other community settings outside households

name: COS headcount 20 years and older
definition: Individual client 20 years and above, attended to by WBPHCOT in the household
definitionExtended: Count each client once for each day they are visited in the household, regardless of the number of services provided on that day
useAndContext: Monitors implementation of Policy Framework and Strategy for WBPHCOT
inclusions: INCLUDE All individual clients 20 years and above, attended to by WBPHCOT in the household and other community settings outside households

name: COS headcount 5-9 years
definition: Individual client 5 to 9 years attended to by WBPCHOT in the household
definitionExtended: Count each client once for each day they are visited in the household, regardless of the number of services provided on that day
useAndContext: Monitors implementation of Policy Framework and Strategy for WBPHCOT
inclusions: INCLUDE All individual client 5 years to under 10 years, attended to by WBPCHOT in the household and other community settings outside households

name: COS headcount under 5 years
definition: Individual client under 5 years (59 months), attended to by WBPHCOT in the household
definitionExtended: Count each client once for each day they are visited in the household, regardless of the number of services provided on that day
useAndContext: Monitors implementation of Policy Framework and Strategy for WBPHCOT
inclusions: INCLUDE All individual clients under 5 years (59 months), attended to by WBPHCOT in the household

name: COS household 1st visit
definition: Households visited for the 1st time by CHW to conduct household  profiling and registration
definitionExtended: All households visited for first time and registration of household members completed
useAndContext: Monitors implementation of PHC WBOT policy
inclusions: INCLUDE All households visited for the first time with household registration completed
exclusions: EXCLUSION All households visited for the first time where household registrations were not completed for various  reasons (e.g. household members not at home)

name: COS household follow-up visit
definition: Households visited to provide follow-up health care support, based on the client’s needs
definitionExtended: All households visited as follow-up and services provided to  household member/s
useAndContext: Monitors implementation of PHC WBOT policy
inclusions: INCLUDE All households visited for the follow-up and services were provided to household members
exclusions: EXCLUSON All households visited for the follow-up but no services were provided to household members

name: Cervical cancer screening  in non-HIV woman 30-50 years
definition: Women aged between  30 -50 years who had a cervical cancer screen using any method (Pap Smear, VIA, OR LBC are included)
definitionExtended: The policy states that women must be screened for cervical cancer at least 3 times in a lifetime. Women should be screened every 10 years from the age of 30 years. Only smears and liquid base screenings done for women in the specified age category should be counted here. The smear must be sufficient to enable quality screening (i.e. include endocervical cells)
useAndContext: Monitors the implementation of the cervical cancer screening policy
inclusions: INCLUDE smears done during antenatal care

name: Cervical cancer screening in HIV positive women 20 years and older
definition: Cervical cancer screening done in HIV positive women at three years intervals using any method (Pap Smear, VIA, or LBC are included)
definitionExtended: The cervical cancer policy states that HIV positive women must be screened for cervical cancer every 3 years from the age of 20 years. Only smears and liquid base done for women in the specified age category should be counted here. The smear must be sufficient to enable quality screening (i.e. include endo and exo-cervical cells)
useAndContext: Monitors the implementation of the cervical cancer screening policy
inclusions: INCLUDE diagnostic smears irrespective of intervals
exclusions: EXCLUDE repeat smears where smear is insufficient due to lack of endocervical cells

name: IUCD inserted
definition: Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD) inserted into a woman aged 15-49 years
definitionExtended: Count each IUCD inserted. IUCD’s are relatively uncommon in developing countries, and the numbers are small compared to e.g. injectable or oral contraceptives. Facility numbers above 10 during one reporting period should be verified
useAndContext: Monitors couple year protection rate
inclusions: INCLUDE referrals to a General Practitioner to insert the IUCD when the IUCD is supplied by the facility
exclusions: EXCLUDE IUCD inserted to women younger than 15 years of age and older than 49 years of age

name: Medroxyprogesterone injection
definition: Medroxyprogesterone acetate (Depo Provera/Petogen) injection given to a woman aged 15-49 years
definitionExtended: Count each medroxyprogesterone acetate injection given. This injection provides protection against pregnancy for 3 months. Do not mix up the Medroxyprogesterone and Norethisterone enanthate injections
useAndContext: Monitors couple year protection rate
exclusions: EXCLUDE Medroxyprogesterone acetate (Depo Provera/Petogen) injection given to women younger than 15 years of age and older than 49 years of age

name: Norethisterone enanthate injection
definition: Norethisterone enanthate injection given to a woman aged 15-49 years
definitionExtended: Count each norethisterone enanthate injection given. This injection provides protection against pregnancy for 2 months. Do not mix up Medroxyprogesterone and Norethisterone enanthate injections
useAndContext: Monitors couple year protection rate
exclusions: EXCLUDE Norethisterone enanthate injection given to women younger than 15 years of age and older than 49 years of age

name: Oral pill cycle
definition: A packet (cycle) of oral contraceptives issued to a woman aged 15-49 years
definitionExtended: Count each packet issued. Each cycle containing pills for one cycle (28 days). The packets issued per client would normally range from around 3 given to e.g. new/young users that need closer monitoring for side effects and up to 6 given to older women that have used pills for many years without known side-effects
useAndContext: Monitors couple year protection rate
exclusions: EXCLUDE oral contraceptive pills given for the treatment of breakthrough bleedings on Medroxyprogesterone injection

name: Sterilisation - female
definition: Surgical procedure to protect a woman from further pregnancy
definitionExtended: Interval and post-partum sterilizations should be counted. The sterilisation can be performed by means of a mini-laparotomy or laparoscopic procedure. Count each case only in the facility where the operation is actually performed
useAndContext: Monitors couple year protection rate

name: Sterilisation - male
definition: Surgical procedure to prevent a man from being fertile
definitionExtended: Also called vasectomy. Count each case when the operation is actually performed
useAndContext: Monitors couple year protection rate

name: Sub-dermal implant inserted
definition: Subdermal contraceptive implant inserted just under the skin on upper arm of a woman aged 15-49 years
definitionExtended: Count each contraceptive implant inserted. The subdermal contraceptive implant is active for 2.5 years
useAndContext: Monitors couple year protection rate
exclusions: EXCLUDE subdermal contraceptive implants inserted to women younger than 15 years of age and older than 49 years of age

name: Termination of pregnancy 0-12 weeks
definition: Termination of Pregnancy in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy performed under safe conditions in a designated health facility
definitionExtended: Count each case ONLY in the designated facility where the termination is actually performed
useAndContext: Monitors the implementation of the termination of pregnancy policy
exclusions: EXCLUDE therapeutic TOPs

name: Termination of pregnancy 10-14 years
definition: Termination of pregnancy 10 to 14 years performed under safe conditions in a designated health facility
definitionExtended: Count each case ONLY in the (designated facility where the termination is actually performed
useAndContext: Monitors the implementation of the termination of pregnancy policy
exclusions: EXCLUDE therapeutic TOPs

name: Termination of pregnancy 13-20 weeks
definition: Termination of Pregnancy at 13-20 weeks of pregnancy performed under safe conditions in a designated health facility
definitionExtended: Count each case ONLY in the designated facility where the termination is actually performed
useAndContext: Monitors the implementation of the termination of pregnancy policy
exclusions: EXCLUDE therapeutic TOPs

name: Termination of pregnancy 15-19 years
definition: Termination of pregnancy 15 to 19 years performed under safe conditions in a designated health facility
definitionExtended: Count each case ONLY in the designated facility where the termination is actually performed
useAndContext: Monitors the implementation of the termination of pregnancy policy
exclusions: EXCLUDE therapeutic TOPs

name: Termination of pregnancy 20 years and older
definition: Termination of Pregnancy 20 years and older performed under safe conditions in a designated health facility
definitionExtended: Count each case ONLY in the designated facility where the termination is actually performed
useAndContext: Monitors the implementation of the termination of pregnancy policy
exclusions: EXCLUDE therapeutic TOPs

name: chairs and recliners (e.g. as used for renal dialysis patients etc.); EXCLUDE: High Care and ICU neonatal beds
shortname: cots for normal neonates (well baby cots)

name: disruptive
shortname: neurocognitive disorders like dementia and organic brain disease
definition: neurodevelopmental disorders like attention deficit hyperactivity disorders
definitionExtended: autism spectrum disorders etc.
